The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.

items.item_details:
California Education Code Section 76355 provides the governing board the option of increasing the student health services fee by the same percentage as the Implicit Price Deflator for State and Local Government Purchase of Goods and Services.
	 
The District received notification from the California State Chancellor's Office in August 2011 that the index has increased enough since the last fee increase in 2007 to support a $1 increase to the fee.
	 
Fees collected in Fiscal Year 2010-2011 totaled $610,013; however, were not enough to support the operations.  Evergreen Valley College supplemented the program by transferring $14,830 from its General Fund budget (Fund 10).  San Jose City College transferred $25,082 in expenses to its MAA Budget in the Categorical and Grant Fund (Fund 17).  It is anticipated that the $1 increase will yield approximately $35,000 in additional revenue to support the Student Health Centers.
	 
The proposed fee increase has been vetted through each campus' shared governance process.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Student Health fee increase of $1 per semester to $18.

items.item_details:
On January 26, 2012, our Maintenance Supervisor communicated with the District Office that there was an underground leak supplying heating hot water to the Sequoia Building and Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College. This hot water is leaking into EVC’s tunnel, through some electrical/IT conduit and gradually getting worse. If this were to continue, not only will it waste water, the District will be unable to supply any heat to the Sequoia Building and Lecture Hall. The cause of this leak was due to poor or improper installation. To properly remedy this issue, we must abandon the existing pipe that is currently in place and install 120 feet of new pipe from the tunnel. Because of this situation, the District did not seek formal bids as the delay in installing 120 feet of new piping expose staff and the District to dangers of life and property.
	 
Although the District did not seek formal bids, the District did seek three informal bids. The District invoked California Public contract Code Section 20654, which states that “In an emergency when any repairs, alterations, work or improvements is necessary to any facility of the college, or to permit the continuance of existing college classes, or to avoid danger to life or property, the board may by unanimous vote, with the approval of the county superintendent of schools… make a contract in writing or otherwise on behalf of the district for the performance of labor and furnishing of materials or supplies for the purpose without advertising for or inviting bids.” The District received approval from Dr. Charles Weis, Santa Clara County Superintendent of Schools.
	 
Therefore, it is recommended that the Board of Trustees unanimously approve and award the contract to Thermal Mechanical, Inc. in the amount of $39,395.00 for the emergency upgrade of 120 feet of pipe that supplies heating water to the Sequoia Building and Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College "without advertising for or inviting bids” “to avoid the danger of life or property.”
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award the contract to Thermal Mechanical, Inc. for the emergency replacement of 120 feet of piping, supplying heating hot water to the Sequoia Building and Lecture Hall at Evergreen Valley College.

Since 2005, the Workforce Institute has contracted with the City of San Jose to provide WIA Older Youth intensive services and is continuing those services for the 2011-12 program year.  Services include eligibility determination, assessment, counseling/case management, job development/placement services, for youth ages 17-21, who are low income with at least one barrier to obtaining employment. This program offers the WorkKeys Career Readiness Certificate, National Retail Federation's Customer Service Training and a choice of enrollment into the San Jose Promise Program, Pathways to Teaching, Hospitality Training or Building Systems Maintenance Technician Training. Upon completion of training, participants receive one-on-one job placement assistance. Incentives and supportive services are offered throughout the program to ensure that the participants finish the program.
	 
The City of San Jose's work2future has requested additional supportive services (transportation assistance, interview clothing, and tuition assistance), additional incentives (such as Target Gift Cards), or other incentives and is amending the original $486,000 WIA Youth contract approved by the SJECCD Board of Trustees on August 9, 2011. The amended contract provides $71,370 in new funding for a new contract total of $557,370.
The amended contract provides $71,370 in new funding for supportive services and incentives for WIA Youth participants.

Program services are also delivered to employers in Santa Clara County. These services include placement assistance, job fair participation, and National Career Readiness Certificate test proctoring. These services are provided at the San Jose One Stop, the Campbell One Stop and the Gilroy One Stop.
	 
The City of San Jose's work2future has requested that Workforce Institute provide additional WorkKeys National Career Readiness Certifications and is amending the original $385,000 WIA Adult contract approved by the SJECCD Board of Trustees on August 9, 2011. items.item_details:
In May 2009, the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District issued $46,775,000 of Taxable OPEB Bonds in order to pre-fund the District’s liability for retiree benefits and to provide general fund relief.  The Bonds were initially sold to U.S. Bank with a fixed interest rate of 4.62% for three years.  At the end of the three-year period (May 14, 2012), the Bonds will be relinquished by U.S. Bank and may be reissued in a variable interest rate mode with payments to be made under a floating-to-fixed interest rate swap agreement.
	 
During the past couple of months, the District’s OPEB Bond Finance Team has explored several financing options for the OPEB Bond restructuring.  The two best options will be presented to the Board this evening by a representative from Piper Jaffray, Mr. Timothy Carty.  Mr. Carty will go over the two options that will 1) lock-in historically low interest rates and 2) provide a long-term solution for the District’s OPEB Bonds.
	 
Once the Finance Team receives approval from the Board, it will move into action immediately to lock down an interest rate.  It will then take about 30-60 days to complete the legal paperwork commemorating the OPEB Bond restructuring.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 021412-5 to authorize the District Administration to proceed with financing options for the restructuring of the District’s Outstanding 2009 Taxable OPEB (Other Post-Employment Benefit) Bonds

Division of the State Architect (DSA) plan review and construction oversight is governed by the provisions of the Field Act contained in the California Education Code sections 81130, et. seq. for community colleges.  Their review focuses on new construction and alteration projects for California community college districts.  The Field Act imposes important requirements on California schools that are not present in other types of construction approval processes.  
	 
The Evergreen Valley College Central plant and Police Renovation and Remodel project falls under this jurisdiction.  A fee is required to be paid to the DSA at the beginning of the design process.  For this project the DSA fee is $127,500.  (The final fee value will be adjusted based on the final construction cost of the project after completion of the work.) 
	 
The Board of Trustees is asked to approve issuance of a fee payment to the DSA in the amount of $127,500.

On December 13, the Board of Trustees acted to adopt a resolution for transmittal to the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges urging them to delay their approval of the Student Success Task Force Recommendations to permit more time for system deliberation.  In addition, the board established a Board Subcommittee on Student Success. The Charge to the Subcommittee was to compare, contrast and analyze these various sources and to present a set of policy constructs that is consonant with the Board's direction as adopted in its Workplan.
	 
On January 9, 2012, the Board of Governors approved the Student Success Task Force Recommendations and proceeded immediately to propose legislation to implement said recommendations.  The purpose of this resolution is to reaffirm this board's opposition to the process and procedures identified in the recommendations and to request that Chancellor Cepeda provide the board with a study of the “impact” of the SSTF Recommendations on our District.  This study will be used to provide the framework and necessary guidelines for  board members to engage in advocacy as they provide direct input through the legislative process.

items.item_details:
On Saturday, January 21, 2012, 500+ attendees converged on the campus of Evergreen Valley College to participate in a full-day summit and evening reception from 8:30 a.m. - 9:30 p.m.  Senior Obama Administration officials from diverse policy areas and bay area leaders in business, education, non-profit, and other sectors as well as local officials discussed issues critical to the Latino community in San Jose, the region, the state and the nation.  
	 
	After attendees "pitched" 38 session topics (e.g., "Community College Access, Success and Equity," "Latino Job creation in the apps economy," "Closing the Education Achievement Gap," "Empowering Entrepreneurs," "Global Exports/Commerce, "Retirement Income Stream," and "Immigration/Dream Act"), members of the Obama Administration and participants broke into discussion topic teams within two buildings--Gullo I and Gullo II--to engage in robust conversation and networking around the Latino community's concerns, successes and solutions for each session.   
	 
	Tonight, we acknowledge the phenomenal work of the planning committee and student ambassadors who pulled off an incredibly successful event (with the highest attendance of any summit to date) in just 12 short days. 
	 
	A brief report and 3+ minute video capturing event highlights will be provided by Rosalie Ledesma, Chief Assistant to the Chancellor, and chair of the planning committee.  Immediately following, planning committee members will be recognized and student ambassador certificates will be awarded.

items.item_details:
The SJECCD Chapter of Latina Leadership Network (LLN) was asked to help establish a scholarship with the SJECCD Foundation in honor of Maria Romo.  Ms. Romo was a community activist, distinguished member of LLN and long-time employee of San Jose State University.  She was also heavily involved with EOP&S programs statewide, serving on Evergreen Valley College’s advisory committee.  
	 
The amount of the scholarship has not yet been established and will depend on LLN’s fundraising efforts.  Since Ms. Romo was a single parent and an AB540 advocate, this target population will be highly considered as recipients of her scholarship.
	 
This presentation is LLN’s way of communicating this information to the Board of Trustees and the district community as a whole.
